repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
```
	This option is obsolete; |paste| is handled automatically.
```

Should we also document what it does?

```
	Enables "paste mode":
		- mappings in Insert mode and Command-line mode are disabled
		- abbreviations are disabled
		- 'autoindent' is reset
		- 'expandtab' is reset
		- 'formatoptions' is used like it is empty
		- 'revins' is reset
		- 'ruler' is reset
		- 'showmatch' is reset
		- 'smartindent' is reset
		- 'smarttab' is reset
		- 'softtabstop' is set to 0
		- 'textwidth' is set to 0
		- 'wrapmargin' is set to 0
	These options keep their value, but their effect is disabled:
		- 'cindent'
		- 'indentexpr'
		- 'lisp'
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -145,6 +145,7 @@ OPTIONS
 - 'viewoptions'		Flags "unix", "slash" are ignored and always enabled.
 - *'viminfo'*		Deprecated alias to 'shada' option.
 - *'viminfofile'*	Deprecated alias to 'shadafile' option.
+- *'paste'* *'nopaste'*

 call <SID>OptionG("cpo", &cpo)
-call <SID>AddOption("paste", gettext("paste mode, insert typed text literally"))

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• 'paste' option is now deprecated and 'pastetoggle' is removed. |paste| works
  automatically in GUI and terminal (TUI) Nvim.  Just Paste It.™
```

   - The `concat` option has been removed as it was not consistently applied.
   - Invalid ranges now cause an error instead of returning `nil`.
 
+• 'paste' option is now deprecated and 'pastetoggle' is removed

comment_regular_data.body:
we cannot remove 'paste'. It is very common in plugins and configs.

'pastetoggle' can and should be removed though, it's a total waste of everyone's time because it generates bug reports and doesn't work well, and is useless because bracketed-paste works better.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/10867 removes 'pastetoggle' and has some doc changes also.
'paste' may have to be used internally in the future. #17723

> 'paste' may have to be used internally in the future. #17723

yeah, though in theory `nvim_buf_set_text()` or similar should handle this kind of thing. Related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19806
I don't really like the way it's named. It would be better to have something like `vim.clipboard.get() ... set()`

Can `paste/nopaste` really be deprecated, or am I missing something here? 

For example, using in insert mode doing `<C-r">`  (or any other register), still pastes with the wrong formatting, Furthermore, not all UI's implement paste, for example Neovide currently does not,  although it probably should, I guess by calling `nvim_paste`?

Thanks, yes that works, I had forgot that mapping since I rarely paste from insert and almost never any longer text. That along with its siblings `<C-R><C-P>` and `<C-R><C-R>` are superior alternatives in most cases.

But I feel like they should be documented as alternatives in the deprecated section though. `set paste` is a common recommendation when you search for "paste in vim insert mode without formatting" in Google. So, it's likely that many people are relying on either that or `pastetoggle`

> For example, using in insert mode doing `<C-r">` (or any other register), still pastes with the wrong formatting, 

We should change that. `<c-r>{clipboard}` should work just like `vim.paste()`, it shouldn't try to be "smart".

> Furthermore, not all UI's implement paste, for example Neovide currently does not, although it probably should, I guess by calling `nvim_paste`?

yes, see `:help dev-ui`

@justinmk is there something special I need to do with `CTRL-R CTRL-P {register}`?

For me, it still isn't fixing the indenting. I have to try to use visual selection and `=` and then its actually fixed.

@justinmk to further explain the problem, in my quest to move to Neovim I decided to fix all the annoyances that have accrued over 10+ years of using vim/macvim.

One of those is is that pasting something "just works", regardless of whether its:

1. insert mode, normal mode, visual mode, visual line mode... visual block mode is another story but I don't care about that
2. single word, single line, or multi-line

You would think this would be relatively straightforward, given that pretty much all other IDE's can do this properly (like VSCode, blah blah blah).

I'm struggling with a number of things, but basically

1. when using `"+P` it seems to not paste at the beginning/end of cursor properly. For a single word, the cursor goes at the end regardless of whether I choose `p` or `P`, and when its multi-line, the cursor always remains at the start. This makes it really hard to do things like using `m` marks to highlight what was just pasted so I can format it.
2. The better option would be if there was some way to paste+format at the same time in insert/normal mode both. I see `<C-r><C-p>` as well as `<C-r><C-o>` for insert mode, but in BOTH those cases, the indenting is just wrong.

For example, just pasting this:

```
{
  'filetype',
  colored = false,
  icon_only = false,
  icon = { align = 'right' },
}
```

Into a LUA config file indents improperly with both RP and RO.

And this is only insert mode, with normal mode it seems I have to use marks and that is impossible due to what I mentioned with the cursor not consistently going to the beginning and the end.

I've also tried using `'[` and `']` but for whatever reason, it doesnt actually go exactly to the end and the start, for some reason its always off for some scenario.

I'm no neovim expert, and not a vim configuration expert, so I could be doing something completely wrong.

So far these were my attempts, all of them semi-broken. (These specific commands are being used with Neovide to replace macviM)

```
  vim.keymap.set('v', '<D-x>', '"+d')                 -- cut
  vim.keymap.set('v', '<D-c>', '"+y')                 -- copy
  vim.keymap.set('i', '<D-v>', '<C-r><C-o>+')         -- paste insert mode
  vim.keymap.set('n', '<D-v>', 'm0"+P`]m`v`0=``')     -- paste normal mode
  vim.keymap.set('v', '<D-v>', '"+P`]')               -- paste visual mode
  vim.keymap.set('c', '<D-v>', '<C-r>+')              -- paste command mode
```

> pasting something "just works", regardless of whether its:
> 
> 1. insert mode, normal mode, visual mode, visual line mode... visual block mode

@9mm that is also the case in Nvim if you use "OS paste". I assume you were using "OS paste" (cmd+v) in macvim. Compare apples to apples.

Doing that for `+"p` and friends is a separate topic. 

> So far these were my attempts, all of them semi-broken.

Macvim is a GUI, so `<d-v>` (cmd+v) works there. Whether that works in your terminal is between you and your terminal.

This isn't a support thread, use https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions for questions.
